page.title: 01REVIEW
page.content: {This}is an area of sparsely populated countryside, undulating gently from a height of 261 metres in the West to 42 metres in the East. Much of the land is under crops but a great deal of the land cover is rough grazing. {The}land is dissected by several small streams flowing from West to East, which eventually join the Tweed, Midlem Burn being the most important. There are small plantations of coniferous and deciduous trees acting mainly as wind-breaks or fox coverts. {The}main centre of settlement is found at the village of Midlem (population 92) the remainder being small farms and isolated houses. {The}A699 from St Boswells to Selkirk crosses from the North-East to the West and there are a number of secondary roads and footpaths.
